metadata.titleEn: Monthly mean evapotranspiration data set of the Tibet Plateau (2001-2018)
metadata.description: This data set includes the monthly average actual evapotranspiration of the Tibet Plateau from 2001 to 2018. The data set is based on the satellite remote sensing data (MODIS) and reanalysis meteorological data (CMFD), and is calculated by the surface energy balance system model (SEBS). In the process of calculating the turbulent flux, the sub-grid scale topography drag parameterization scheme is introduced to improve the simulation of sensible and latent heat fluxes. In addition, the evapotranspiration of the model is verified by the observation data of six turbulence flux stations on the Tibetan Plateau, which shows high accuracy. The data set can be used to study the characteristics of land-atmosphere interaction and the water cycle in the Tibetan Plateau.
metadata.instructions: Data storage format is standard NetCDF format, including time, longitude and latitude information, which can be read directly by NCL, python, MATLAB and other software.

background: As the birthplace of Asia’s major rivers, the Tibetan Plateau (TP), famous as the “Water Tower of Asia”, is essential to the Asian energy and water cycles (Immerzeel et al., 2010; Yao et al., 2012). Consuming around two-thirds of global terrestrial precipitation, evapotranspiration (ET) is a crucial component that affects the exchange of water and energy between the land surface and the atmosphere (Oki and Kanae, 2006; Fisher et al., 2017). ET is also a key factor modulating regional and global weather and climate. Total evaporation from large lakes of the TP has been quantitatively estimated recently (B. Wang et al., 2020); however, the terrestrial ET on the TP and its spatial and temporal changes remain very uncertain. Although Epan and potential ET suggest the long-term variability in ET according to the complementary relationship (CR) between Epan and actual ET (ET a) (Zhang et al., 2007), these measures cannot precisely depict the spatial pattern of trends in ET a. Employing only routine meteorological observations without requiring any vegetation and soil information is the most significant advantage of CR models (Szilagyi et al., 2017). However, numerous assumptions and requirements of validations of key parameters limit the application and performance of CR models over different climate conditions. Satellite remote sensing (RS) provides temporally frequent and spatially contiguous measurements of land surface characteristics that affect ET, for example, land surface temperature, albedo, and vegetation index.
research objective: Thus, in this study, with full consideration of the recent developments in the SEBS model over the TP, we aim to (1) develop an 18-year (2001–2018) ET a product of the TP, along with independent validations against EC observations; (2) quantify the spatiotemporal variability in the ET a in the TP; and (3) uncover the main factors dominating the changes in ETa, using the estimated product.
challenges: However, spatial distribution and temporal changes in ET a over the Tibetan Plateau (TP) remain very uncertain. However, the fetch of the EC observation is on the order of hundreds of meters, thus impeding the ability to capture the plateau-scale variations in ET a. However, numerous assumptions and requirements of validations of key parameters limit the application and performance of CR models over different climate conditions. The SEBS-estimated ETa is at a resolution of around 10 km, while the footprint of EC-observed ETa values ranges from a few dozen meters to a few hundred meters. Note that the energy consumption related to freeze–thaw processes and sublimation is neglected. Thus, the dataset is likely to be less reliable over the glacier and permafrost and in the winter season.
methods: The SEBS model (Su, 2002) was used to derive land surface energy flux components in the present study. The SEBS-estimated ETa was validated against EC observations at six flux stations on the TP at a monthly scale. In situ observations, satellite-based products, and meteorological forcing data were used in this study to estimate monthly ETa over the TP area. The 3-hourly CMFD data were averaged into daily and then into monthly data to be consistent with MODIS products in terms of temporal resolution.
dataset: The CMFD, which was developed based on the released China Meteorological Administration (CMA) data (He et al., 2020), was used as model input. MODIS monthly land surface products, including land surface temperature and emissivity, land surface albedo, and vegetation index, provide land surface conditions for the SEBS model. In situ EC data observed at six flux stations on the TP were used to validate model results. The dataset presented and analyzed in this article has been released and is available for free download from the Science Data Bank (https://doi.org/10.11922/sciencedb.t00000.00010, Han et al., 2020b) and from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center (https://doi.org/10.11888/Hydro.tpdc.270995, Han et al., 2020a).
findings: The domain mean of annual ETa on the TP decreased slightly (−1.45 mm yr−1, p< 0.05) from 2001 to 2018. The annual ETa increased significantly at a rate of 2.62 mm yr−1 (p< 0.05) in the eastern sector of the TP (long >90◦E) but decreased significantly at a rate of −5.52 mm yr−1 (p< 0.05) in the western sector of the TP (long <90◦E). The mean annual ET a during 2001–2018 and over the whole TP was 496 ±23 mm. Thus, the total evapotranspiration from the terrestrial surface of the TP was 1238.3±57.6 km3 yr−1.

Concept Completion.Answer: uncertainties in spatial distribution and temporal changes in evapotranspiration

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to estimate evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to estimate evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau involves using the SEBS model, which combines satellite remote sensing data (such as MODIS products) and reanalysis meteorological data (like CMFD) to compute surface energy flux components. This method incorporates in situ EC data from six flux stations on the plateau to validate the model outputs.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered when modeling evapotranspiration over the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in modeling evapotranspiration over the Tibetan Plateau is the uncertainty in capturing plateau-scale variations in evapotranspiration due to the limited spatial footprint of EC observations, which ranges from a few dozen meters to a few hundred meters, compared to the larger resolution of the SEBS-estimated data.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used for validating evapotranspiration model results in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used for validating evapotranspiration model results in the Tibetan Plateau region is the in situ EC data observed at six flux stations on the TP. These data were used to validate the SEBS model results at a monthly scale, ensuring the accuracy of the estimated evapotranspiration.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used to estimate evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: satellite remote sensing data, MODIS products, land surface conditions, temperature, albedo, vegetation index, meteorological forcing data from CMFD, in situ EC observations at six flux stations, monthly estimation

Feature Specification.Question: What are the primary challenges in accurately measuring evapotranspiration spatially and temporally on the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: uncertainty in spatial distribution, temporal changes, limited spatial coverage of EC observations, assumptions and validation requirements of key parameters, energy consumption related to freeze-thaw processes and sublimation neglected

Quantification.Question: How many flux stations provided in-situ EC data for validating the SEBS model estimations on the Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What is the SEBS model in the context of evapotranspiration estimation on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: The SEBS model, as used in the context of evapotranspiration estimation on the Tibetan Plateau, is a method to derive land surface energy flux components. It incorporates satellite remote sensing data and meteorological inputs to estimate actual evapotranspiration, validated against EC observations at flux stations.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with using complementary relationship models for evapotranspiration estimation?
Definition.Answer: The challenges of using complementary relationship models for evapotranspiration estimation include numerous assumptions and requirements for validating key parameters, which limit their application across different climate conditions. These models do not require vegetation and soil information but face limitations in accurately depicting spatial and temporal patterns of actual evapotranspiration.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in spatial resolution and validation methods between the SEBS model-estimated evapotranspiration data and EC observation data on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: The SEBS model estimates evapotranspiration at a resolution of around 10 km, whereas the EC observation data have a footprint that ranges from a few dozen meters to a few hundred meters. The SEBS model's estimated data were validated against EC observations at six flux stations on a monthly scale.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do satellite-based products and in situ observations complement each other in the data collection for evapotranspiration modeling over the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Satellite-based products, such as MODIS, provide temporally frequent and spatially contiguous measurements of land surface characteristics affecting evapotranspiration, while in situ observations from EC data at flux stations are used to validate the model results. This combination allows for the estimation of monthly evapotranspiration over a large area like the Tibetan Plateau.

Interpretation.Question: How can satellite remote sensing data be integrated with in situ observations to improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates over diverse climate conditions?
Interpretation.Answer: Satellite remote sensing provides temporally frequent and spatially contiguous measurements of land surface characteristics like temperature, albedo, and vegetation index, which affect evapotranspiration. In situ observations, such as those from flux stations, can validate satellite-derived estimates. This integration can enhance accuracy by combining the spatial coverage of remote sensing with the precision of ground-based measurements, addressing challenges posed by varied climate conditions.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological challenges arise from the use of land surface energy balance models in estimating evapotranspiration in areas with complex terrain such as the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: One challenge is the scale discrepancy between the model's resolution and the footprint of ground observations, which can affect accuracy. Additionally, energy consumption related to freeze-thaw processes and sublimation is often neglected, leading to potential reliability issues in glacier and permafrost regions and during winter. The model's assumptions and parameter validations also limit its application across different climate conditions.

Interpretation.Question: What are the key factors dominating changes in actual evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau, and how can they be quantified using data collected over an extended period?
Interpretation.Answer: Key factors include spatial and temporal variability in land surface characteristics influenced by climate change and human activities. These can be quantified using an 18-year dataset of actual evapotranspiration, validated against ground observations, to identify trends and patterns. The data's temporal depth and spatial coverage allow for a detailed analysis of changes and their driving factors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes uncertainties in the spatial distribution and temporal changes in terrestrial evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The uncertainties arise due to the fetch of the EC observation being on the order of hundreds of meters, which impedes the ability to capture the plateau-scale variations in evapotranspiration. Additionally, numerous assumptions and requirements of validations of key parameters limit the application and performance of CR models over different climate conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary reasons for the contrasting trends in annual evapotranspiration between the eastern and western sectors of the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The contrasting trends are due to the significant increase in annual evapotranspiration at a rate of 2.62 mm yr−1 in the eastern sector (longitude >90◦E) and a significant decrease at a rate of −5.52 mm yr−1 in the western sector (longitude <90◦E) from 2001 to 2018.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of excluding energy consumption related to freeze–thaw processes and sublimation in the estimation of evapotranspiration over glacier and permafrost regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Excluding energy consumption related to freeze–thaw processes and sublimation may result in less reliable evapotranspiration estimates over glacier and permafrost regions, especially during the winter season, affecting the accuracy of the dataset used for studying the Tibetan Plateau.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodology would be appropriate to validate an evapotranspiration dataset using ground-based observations in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The SEBS-estimated evapotranspiration was validated against eddy covariance (EC) observations at six flux stations on the Tibetan Plateau at a monthly scale, using in situ observations to ensure the accuracy of the dataset.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can satellite remote sensing data be integrated with meteorological data to estimate monthly evapotranspiration in a complex terrain like the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Satellite-based products such as MODIS land surface temperature, emissivity, albedo, and vegetation index are combined with meteorological forcing data, like the China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD), to estimate monthly evapotranspiration over the Tibetan Plateau using the SEBS model.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in adjusting data resolution to match different datasets for modeling land surface energy flux in the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves averaging 3-hourly CMFD data into daily and then into monthly data to maintain consistency with the temporal resolution of MODIS products, ensuring that the data can be effectively used in the SEBS model for estimating land surface energy flux components.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methodologies enable the validation of model outputs against in situ observations in challenging environments like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Validation of model outputs is enabled by using in situ EC data observed at six flux stations on the Tibetan Plateau. These observations provide a benchmark for model validation despite challenges like the spatial scale differences between the model estimates and the footprint of EC observations.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected precision in capturing plateau-scale variations in evapotranspiration be limited when using flux station data?
Expectation.Answer: The fetch of the EC observation is on the order of hundreds of meters, thus impeding the ability to capture the plateau-scale variations in ET a. The SEBS-estimated ETa is at a resolution of around 10 km, while the footprint of EC-observed ETa values ranges from a few dozen meters to a few hundred meters.

Expectation.Question: Why are complementary relationship models not expected to perform reliably across different climate conditions without extensive parameter validation?
Expectation.Answer: Numerous assumptions and requirements of validations of key parameters limit the application and performance of CR models over different climate conditions. This necessitates extensive parameter validation to ensure reliability across varying climatic conditions.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think the use of satellite remote sensing data, such as MODIS, is in capturing the spatial variability of evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of satellite remote sensing data like MODIS is effective in providing temporally frequent and spatially contiguous measurements of land surface characteristics that affect evapotranspiration. However, there are uncertainties in capturing the spatial distribution and temporal changes in evapotranspiration, especially when compared to in-situ observations with limited spatial reach.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the limitations of using the SEBS model for estimating evapotranspiration over diverse climatic regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The SEBS model, while useful for deriving land surface energy flux components, faces limitations due to its resolution and assumptions. The model's estimated values are at a resolution of around 10 km, which may not fully capture the variations observed at smaller scales. Additionally, the model's neglect of energy consumption related to freeze–thaw processes and sublimation can affect its reliability over glaciers, permafrost, and during winter.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how spatial distribution and temporal changes in evapotranspiration over the Tibetan Plateau can remain uncertain despite using satellite remote sensing.
Assertion.Answer: Spatial distribution and temporal changes in evapotranspiration over the Tibetan Plateau remain uncertain due to the scale mismatch between the SEBS model's resolution (~10 km) and the smaller footprint of EC-observed evapotranspiration values (from a few dozen meters to a few hundred meters). Additionally, assumptions and the need for validation of key parameters limit the application and performance of complementary relationship models under different climate conditions.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how satellite remote sensing contributes to understanding land surface characteristics that affect evapotranspiration.
Assertion.Answer: Satellite remote sensing provides temporally frequent and spatially contiguous measurements of land surface characteristics such as land surface temperature, albedo, and vegetation index. These measurements are crucial for estimating evapotranspiration as they affect the exchange of water and energy between the land surface and the atmosphere.

Assertion.Question: I don't make sense of why the energy consumption related to freeze-thaw processes and sublimation is neglected in the estimation of evapotranspiration.
Assertion.Answer: The energy consumption related to freeze-thaw processes and sublimation is neglected in the estimation of evapotranspiration, which may affect the reliability of the dataset over glacier and permafrost areas and during the winter season. This is likely due to the complexities and additional data requirements these processes would introduce, which are not addressed in the current modeling approach.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the data collection methods used to obtain evapotranspiration data on the Tibetan Plateau, considering the challenges of spatial and temporal variability.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods involve using the SEBS model to derive land surface energy flux components. This process incorporates satellite remote sensing data, specifically MODIS products, and meteorological forcing data like CMFD. Additionally, in situ EC observations at six flux stations on the Tibetan Plateau are used to validate the model outputs. The challenges include dealing with the footprint of EC-observed ETa values, which are limited to a few dozen meters to a few hundred meters, contrasting with the SEBS-estimated ETa resolution of around 10 km.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the potential challenges and limitations in the application of CR models for estimating evapotranspiration on the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The potential challenges in applying CR models for estimating evapotranspiration include numerous assumptions and validation requirements for key parameters, which limit the models' performance across different climate conditions. Additionally, the energy consumption related to freeze-thaw processes and sublimation is often neglected, making the dataset less reliable over glacier and permafrost areas and during winter.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify datasets that could be used for validating evapotranspiration estimates on the Tibetan Plateau and discuss their significance.
Request/Directive.Answer: Datasets used for validating evapotranspiration estimates include in situ EC data collected at six flux stations on the Tibetan Plateau. These datasets are significant as they provide ground-based observations that help validate satellite-based and model-derived ETa estimates, ensuring higher accuracy and reliability of the data. The CMFD data, developed from China Meteorological Administration data, and MODIS land surface products also provide essential inputs for the SEBS model, contributing to the overall validation process.
